title: How I Exercise With Type 2 Diabetes

content: While living with type 2 diabetes for almost 20 years, I didn’t always have a good relationship with exercise or regular physical activity until about 5 years ago.  Unfortunately, the process of losing my sight gave me the fuel that I needed to get better.

When I got serious about adding exercise to my lifestyle, I was also dealing with vision loss and had to be careful about what exercises I chose to do.  My retina was completely detached from the right eye, and the one in my left eye was also beginning to detach. It left me with a new dilemma to face. I couldn’t even do moderately intense workouts without my eyes bleeding from the retina. So I enlisted the help of my brother, who is a certified personal trainer. He helped me learn how to do the exercises that wouldn’t increase the pressure in my eyes, causing them to bleed.

After a few months of doing low-impact exercises, I began to be able to increase the intensity of my workouts. I was losing weight and building muscle, which led to more regulated blood sugar levels.  Soon after that, I was able to do HIIT workouts without experiencing the bleeding.

content: This period of my life was very significant for me and helped me to stay focused during the pandemic lockdowns. While a lot of folks slowed down, I took advantage of the time and opportunity to get my health back on track. It was very difficult for a lot of people because of the isolation, but pouring all of my effort and concentration into my body and mind truly helped me to work on myself. After the lockdowns, I continued my workout routines and I felt I was doing well.

Then in 2022, I started having some difficulty keeping my numbers down even with the HIIT workouts. This time, I asked some colleagues about how these workouts affected my blood sugar levels. I found out that my body’s adverse reactions to these workouts may have been because of increased stress levels and adrenaline from the intensity of the workouts.

content: Plus, I wasn’t sleeping well, dealing with transitioning my son from being at home all of the time to being back at school. It was stressful for him, which didn’t make him a happy camper at home. During a doctor’s visit with my gynecologist, she suggested that I try lower-impact exercises, such as yoga or Pilates.

content: The best way that I could describe these types of workouts is lots of stretching.  I did these types of workouts for about 3 months. I enjoyed the stretching because it made my body feel very relaxed after the workout, but I was so used to the HIIT workouts that I felt like I needed to increase the intensity a little bit.

Eventually, I found a nice spot between moderate and high intensity. Now, I have been consistent with these workouts. I work out at home using an app that has hundreds of workouts for me to choose from. I am definitely seeing a difference in my blood sugar levels and my body. I can’t wait to see what my A1c will show next month.
